nodes.prefixed:
<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">
 <tei-teiHeader data-origname="teiHeader">
     <tei-fileDesc data-origname="fileDesc">
        <tei-titleStmt data-origname="titleStmt">
           <tei-title data-origname="title">An Account of a Voyage up the River de la Plata, and thence over land to Peru</tei-title>
                       <tei-author data-origname="author">Mons. Acarete du Biscay</tei-author>
            <tei-editor data-origname="editor">Busa's Enthusiasts</tei-editor>

        </tei-titleStmt>
        <tei-publicationStmt data-origname="publicationStmt">
           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-publicationStmt>
        <tei-sourceDesc data-origname="sourceDesc">
           <tei-p data-origname="p" data-empty=""/>
        </tei-sourceDesc>
     </tei-fileDesc>
 </tei-teiHeader>
 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
   <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
   <tei-head data-origname="head">Monsieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru.</tei-head>
     <tei-div data-origname="div">
     <tei-pb n="24" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
      <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">24 A Voyage to Peru</tei-fw>
          <tei-p data-origname="p">
I Left <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>, and took the Road to<tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Cordoua</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>, leaving <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Santa Fe</tei-name></tei-hi> on 
my<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> right hand, of which place take this ac<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>count, <tei-sic data-origname="sic">'tis</tei-sic> a <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Spanish</tei-hi> Settlement 
dependant<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> upon <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>, the Commander is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> no more than a <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Lieutenant</tei-roleName>, 
and does no<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>thing but by order from the <tei-roleName data-origname="roleName">Governor</tei-roleName><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>. <tei-sic data-origname="sic">'Tis</tei-sic> a 
little place con<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>taining 25 Houses, without any Walls, Fortifications, or 
Garrison, distant 80<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Leagues from <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi> Northward,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Situate upon the 
<tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">de la Plata</tei-hi></tei-name>, large<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Vessels might come up to it, were it not<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> for a 
great bank that obstructs the pas<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>sage a little above <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>. 
Ne<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>vertheless <tei-sic data-origname="sic">'tis</tei-sic> a very advantageous Post,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> because <tei-sic data-origname="sic">'tis</tei-sic> the only passage 
from <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name></tei-hi>,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Chili</tei-name></tei-hi> and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name></tei-hi> to <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Paraguay</tei-name></tei-hi>, and in<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> a manner the Magazine of 
the Commodi<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">ties.</tei-fw> 
 <tei-pb n="25" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
         <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">up the <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">R. de la Plata</tei-name> 25</tei-fw>
ties drawn from thence, particularly that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Herb already spoken 
of, which they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> cannot be without in those Provinces.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> The Soil is as good 
and Fertile here as<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> at <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>; and the Town having<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> nothing 
remarkably different from what<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> has been <tei-sic data-origname="sic">observ'd</tei-sic> of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>, I<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> leave 
it, and proceed upon my Jour<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ney. <tei-sic data-origname="sic">'Tis</tei-sic> counted 140 Leagues from<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos 
<tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi> to <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Cordoua</tei-orig></tei-name></tei-hi>, and because<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> some parts of the Road are uninhabited<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> for a 
long way together; I surnished<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> my self at my departure with what I<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> was 
<tei-sic data-origname="sic">inform'd</tei-sic> I should stand in need<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> of; so I set out having a Savage for my<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
Guide, with Three Horses and Three<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Mules, some to carry my Baggage, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
the rest to change upon the way when<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> that I rid upon was tired.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
From <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-hi>, to the River <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Lu<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>can</tei-hi>, and even as far as the <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River 
<tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Recife</tei-hi></tei-name>,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 30 Leagues, I <tei-sic data-origname="sic">passâ€™d</tei-sic> by several Habita<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tions and Farms cultivated 
by the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="OrgName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Spani<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ards</tei-name></tei-hi>, but beyond <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Recife</tei-name></tei-hi> to the <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Salladillo</tei-hi></tei-name>, I saw none. 
Let it be obser<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ved by the way, that these Rivers as well<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> as all the rest 
in the Provinces of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name>, <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Paraguay</tei-name> and <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name>, that fall<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> into the 
<tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River de la Plata</tei-name> are fordable on Horse-back; but when the Rains or<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">any</tei-fw> 
     <tei-pb n="26" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
      <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">26 A Voyage to Peru</tei-fw>
any other accident swells them, a Tra<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>veller must either swim over, or else get<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
upon a bundle in the nature of a raft,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> which a Savage hawls over to the 
other<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> side. I could not Swim, and so was<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-sic data-origname="sic">forc'd</tei-sic> to make use of this 
expedient<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> twice or thrice when I could not find a<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Ford. The way was this, 
my Indian<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-sic data-origname="sic">kill'd</tei-sic> a Wild Bull, flead the Hide off,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> stuffed it with straw, 
and <tei-sic data-origname="sic">ty'd</tei-sic> it up in<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> a great bundle with thongs of the same<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Hide, upon which 
I <tei-sic data-origname="sic">plac'd</tei-sic> my self with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> my Baggage ; he swam over hawling me<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> after him by a 
Cord <tei-sic data-origname="sic">ty'd</tei-sic> to the bundle,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> and then he <tei-sic data-origname="sic">repass'd</tei-sic> and swam my Horses<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> and Mules 
over to me.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
All the Country between the <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Recife</tei-name> and <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salladillo</tei-name>, <tei-sic data-origname="sic">tho'</tei-sic> uninhabited,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
abounds in Cattle and all sorts of Fruit-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>trees, except Walnut and Chesnut-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
trees; there are whole Woods of Nectarine-<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Trees, Three or Four Leagues in 
compass,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> that bear excellent Fruit, which they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> not only eat raw, but bake 
them, or dry<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> them in the Sun, to keep, as we in France<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> do Prunes: They 
seldom use any other<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> than the Wood of this Tree for common<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> firing at 
<tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name>, and thereabouts.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> The Savages that dwell in these Parts are<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
distinguish'd into two sorts, those that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">volun-</tei-fw> 
 <tei-pb n="27" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
         <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">up the R. de la Plata 27</tei-fw>
voluntarily submit to the <tei-name type="OrgName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Spaniards</tei-name> are<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> callâ€™d <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign"><tei-orig data-origname="orig"><tei-name type="people" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Panpistas</tei-name></tei-orig></tei-foreign>, the rest <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign"><tei-name type="people" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Serranos</tei-name></tei-foreign>, both<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> cloathed with 
Skins, but the last set up<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>on the <tei-name type="people" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Panpistas</tei-orig></tei-name> as their mortal Enemies<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
wherever they meet with them. All<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Fight on Horse-back, either with Lances<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
pointed with Iron or Bones sharpen'd,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> or else with Bows and Arrows, they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
wear Bulls-hides fashion'd like a Doublet<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> without sleeves, to defend their 
Bodies.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Their Chiefs that command over them<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> in War and Peace, are callâ€™d 
<tei-orig data-origname="orig">Couracas</tei-orig>.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> When they take any one of their Ene<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>mies, alive or dead, they 
meet all toge<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ther, and after they have reproach'd him,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> that either he or 
his Relations were the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> death of their Kindred or Friends, they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> cut and 
tear him into pieces, which they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> roast a little and eat, making a drinking<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
Bowl of his Scull. They feed mostly<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> upon flesh either raw or dress'd, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
particularly Colts flesh, which they like<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> better than Veal. They catch 
abundance<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> of Fish likewise in their Rivers, They<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> have no settled places of 
aboad, but<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ramble up and down, several Families<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> together, and live in 
Tents.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
I could not inform my self exactly<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> what Religion they were of, but I was<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
told that they look'd upon the Sun and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">Moon</tei-fw> 
     <tei-pb n="28" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
      <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">28 A Voyage to Peru</tei-fw>
Moon as Deities and as I travell'd along,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> I saw a Savage upon his knees with his<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Face to the Sun, who cry'd 
out and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> made strange gestures with his Hands<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> and Arms. I learn'd from the 
Savage that<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> accompany'd me, that he was one of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> those they call'd <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">Papas</tei-foreign>, 
who in the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Morning kneel towards the Sun, and at<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Night towards the Moon, 
to supplicate<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> those fancy'd Divinities to be propitious<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> to them, to give 
them fair Weather, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Victory over their Foes.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
They make no great Ceremony in<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> their Marriages ; but when a Relation<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> dies, 
after they have rubbâ€™d his body<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> with a certain Earth that consumes all but<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
the Bones, they preserve them, and carry<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> as many of them as they can 
convenient<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ly about with them in a sort of Chests,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> and this they do in 
token of their af<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>fection to their Kindred ; indeed they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> are not wanting in 
good Offices to them<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> during their Lives, nor in their Sickness<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> and Death.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
Along the <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">River Salladillo</tei-name>, I took<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> notice of a great many Parrats, or 
<tei-orig data-origname="orig">Pa<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>pagays</tei-orig>, as the <tei-name type="OrgName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Spaniards</tei-name> call them, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> certain Birds, callâ€™d 
<tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">Guacamayos</tei-foreign>, whic<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> are of divers Colours, and twice or thrice<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> as big as a 
Parrat. The River it self is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">full-</tei-fw> 
 <tei-pb n="29" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
         <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">up the R. de la Plata 29</tei-fw>
full of the Fish, call'd Dorado, which is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> very good to eat. There is also a Crea<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ture in it, whether 'tis Meat or 
<tei-sic data-origname="sic">Poyson</tei-sic><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> no body knows, it has Four Feet and a<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> long Tail like a Lizard.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
From <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salladillo</tei-name> quite to <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Cordoua</tei-orig></tei-name>, you<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> go along a very fine River, that 
abounds<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> with Fish, which is neither wide nor<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> deep, for it may be forded 
over. On<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> the Bank of it you meet with little Plan<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tations every Three or 
Four Leagues ;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> which are like Country Houses inhabi<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ted by <tei-name type="OrgName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Spaniards</tei-name>, 
<tei-name type="OrgName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Portuguese</tei-name>, and the <tei-name type="people" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Na<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>tives</tei-name>, who have all the necessary acco<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>modations of 
Life they can wish, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> are very Civil and Charitable to Stran<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>gers; their 
principal Wealth is in Hor<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ses and Mules, in which they Trade with<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> the 
Inhabitants of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name>.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
<tei-orig data-origname="orig"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Cordoua</tei-name></tei-orig> is a Town Situate in a pleasant<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> and fruitful Plain upon the side 
of a<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> River, bigger and broader than that I<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> have just spoken of : 'Tis 
composâ€™d of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> about 400 Houses, Built like those of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name>. It has 
neither Ditches,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> nor Walls, nor Fort for its defence; He<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> that Commands it 
is Governor of all<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> the Provinces of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name>, and thoâ€™ it be<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> the place of 
his ordinary Residence, yet<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> he is wont now and then, as he sees oc<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">casion,</tei-fw> 
     <tei-pb n="30" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
      <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">30 A Voyage to Peru</tei-fw>
casion, to go and pass some time at <tei-orig data-origname="orig">St.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Jago de lâ€™Estro</tei-name></tei-orig>, at <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">St. Miguel de Tucuman</tei-name>,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
(which is theCapitalCity of theProvince)<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> at <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salta</tei-name> and at <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Xuxui</tei-name>. In each 
of these<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Villages there is a  <tei-name type="roleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Lieutenant</tei-name>, who has<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> under him an Alcalde and 
some Officer<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> for the Administration of Justice. The<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-name type="roleName" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Bishop</tei-name> of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Tucuman</tei-name> 
likewise usually re<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>sides at <tei-orig data-origname="orig"><tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Cordoua</tei-name></tei-orig>, where the Cathedral<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> is the only 
Parish Church of the whole<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Town ; but there are divers Convents of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Monks, 
namely of <tei-name type="ReligOrder" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Dominican</tei-name>, Recol<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>lects, and those of the <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Order de la Mer<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>cy</tei-orig>: and 
one of Nunns. The <tei-name type="ReligOrder" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Jesuits</tei-name><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> have a College there, and their Chappel<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> is the 
finest and richest of all.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
</tei-p>
<tei-p data-origname="p">
The Inhabitants are Rich in Gold and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Silver, which they get by the Trade<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
they have for Mules, with which they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> furnish <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name> and other Parts; which 
is<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> so considerable, that they sell about 28<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> or 30000 of 'em every Year, 
which they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> breed up in their Farms. They usually<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> keep 'em till they are 
about Two Years<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> old, then expose 'em to Sale, and have<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> about Six Patagons 
a piece for 'em.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> The Merchants that come to buy 'em, carry<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 'em to <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">St. 
Jago</tei-name>, to <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Salta</tei-name> and <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Xuxui</tei-name> ,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> where they leave 'em for Three Years,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> till they 
are well grown and become<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
<tei-fw type="catch" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">strong,-</tei-fw> 
 <tei-pb n="31" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="n" data-empty=""/>
         <tei-fw type="head" data-origname="fw" data-origatts="type">up the R. de la Plata 31</tei-fw>
strong, and afterwards bring 'em to name <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Pe<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>ru</tei-name>, where 
they presently have Vent for<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 'em, because there as well as in the rest<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> of 
the Western part of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">America</tei-name>, the<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> greatest part of their Carriage is upon<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
Mules. The People of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type"><tei-orig data-origname="orig">Cordoua</tei-orig></tei-name> also<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> drive a Trade in Cows, which they have<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> 
from the <tei-sic data-origname="sic">Countrey</tei-sic> of <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Buenos <tei-orig data-origname="orig">Ayres</tei-orig></tei-name>, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> carry to <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Peru</tei-name>, where without this 
way<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> of Subsistance 'tis certain they would<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> have much ado to live. This 
kind of<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> <tei-sic data-origname="sic">Traffick</tei-sic> makes this Town the most con<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>siderable in the <tei-name type="place" data-origname="name" data-origatts="type">Province of 
Tucuman</tei-name>,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> as well for its Riches and Commodities,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> as for the Number of its 
Inhabitants,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> which are counted to be at least 5 or 600 Families, besides 
Slaves who are<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> three times the number. But the gene<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>rality of 'em of all 
degrees have no other<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> Arms but a Sword and Poignard, and<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> are very 
indifferent <tei-sic data-origname="sic">Souldiers</tei-sic>, the Air<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> of the Country, and the Plenty they<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> enjoy, 
rendring them Lazy and Cowardly.<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
          </tei-p>
     </tei-div>
     </tei-body>
 </tei-text>
</tei-TEI>

<tei-TEI data-xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" data-origname="TEI" data-origatts="xmlns:xi xmlns">

 <tei-text data-origname="text">
   <tei-body data-origname="body">
   <tei-pb data-origname="pb" data-empty=""/>
    <tei-head data-origname="head">Viaje de MonsÃ­enr AcÃ¡rete du Biscay desde Buenos Aires hasta el PerÃº</tei-head>
     <tei-div data-origname="div">
          <tei-p data-origname="p">
          SalÃ­ de Buenos Aires y tomÃ© el camino de CÃ³rdoba, dejando Ã¡ Santa Fe Ã¡ mÃ­ 
derecha, de cuyo lugar, hÃ© aquÃ­ una relaciÃ³n:
               Es una poblaciÃ³n espaÃ±ola dependiente de Buenos Aires
siendo el comandante un mero teniente, quien nada hace sin
orden del Gobernador de Buenos Aires. Es una pequeÃ±a poblaciÃ³n, compuesta 
de 25 casas, sin murallas, fortificaciones, ni guarniciÃ³n, distante de 
Buenos Aires 80 leguas al Norte. Situada sobre el Rio de la Plata, buques 
grandes podrÃ­an llegar hasta allÃ­, si no fuese por un gran banco que 
obstruye el paso, un poco mas arriba de Buenos Aires. Sin embargo, es un 
punto muy ventajoso, porque es el Ãºnico paso que hay al Paraguay desde el 
PerÃº, Chile y Tucuman, y en cierto modo es el depÃ³sito de los efectos que 
de allÃ­ se estraen especialmente de la yerba, de la cual ya he hablado,
sin la cual no pueden estar en aquellas Provincias.
El suelo, aqui como en Buenos Aires, es bueno y fÃ©rtil,
y el pueblo, no difiriendo en nada remarcable de lo que ya
hemos observado en Buenos Aires, le dejo y prosigo mi viaje. CuÃ©ntanse 140 
leguas desde Buenos Aires hasta CÃ³rdoba, y por razÃ³n de ser algunas partes 
del camino en largos trechos despoblado, me proveÃ­ Ã¡ mi salida de aquello 
que me dijeron precisarla. PartÃ­, pues, llevando por guia un salvaje, con 
tres caballos y tres muÃ­as, algunas para llevar mi equipaje y el resto 
para mudar en el camino cuando el montado se me cansase.
Desde Buenos Aires hasta el Rio deLucan (1) y aun hasta el Rio Recife (2) 
Ã¡ 30 leguas del pueblo, pasÃ© varias habitaciones y chacras cultivadas por 
los espaÃ±oles, pero mas allÃ¡ del Recife hast i el Rio Saladillo, no vi 
ninguna. ObservarÃ© de paso, que tanto estos rios como los demÃ¡s de las 
provincias de Buenos Aires, Paraguay y Tucuman, que desaguan en el Rio de 
la Plata, son vadeables Ã¡ caballo, pero cuando las lluvias Ã³ cualesquier 
accidente los hace crecer, el viajero se vÃ© obligado Ã¡ atravesarlos 
nadando, sino Ã³ colocarse sobre un bulto en forma de balsa que un salvaje 
pasa tirando al lado opuesto. No sabia yo nadar, y por lo mismo tuve dos Ã³ 
tres veces que acudir Ã¡ este espediente cuando no encontraba paso. El modo 
de verificarlo era este: mi indio mataba un toro, desollÃ¡balo, y 
rellenando

1. Lujan.
2. Arrecifes.

el cuero de paja, cerraba y aseguraba Ã¡ este con correas del
mismo cuero; colocÃ¡bame yo sobre Ã©l, y el indio cruzaba el
rio nadando, llevÃ¡ndome tras de sÃ­ por medio de una soga
atada al bulto; repasando el rio en seguida, hacia pasar Ã¡
nado los caballos y muÃ­as adonde yo estaba.
Todo el paÃ­s entre el Rio Recife y Saladillo, aun cuando
no estÃ¡ poblado, abunda en ganados y Ã¡rboles frutales de
todas clases, menos el nogal y el castaÃ±o. Hay montes enteros de 
durazneros, de tres Ã¡ cuatro leguas de ostensiÃ³n
que producen excelente fruta, que no solo comen ert su estado natural sino 
que tambiÃ©n la cuecen, Ã³ secan al sol, para
conservarla, asÃ­ como hacemos nosotros en Francia con las
ciruelas. En Buenos Aires y sus inmediaciones, raras veces se echa mano de 
otro combustible para los usos comunes, que el de la madera de este Ã¡rbol.
Los salvajes que moran en estos lugares, se dividen en
dos clases; aquellos que se someten voluntariamente Ã¡ los
espaÃ±oles, llÃ¡maseles Pampistas, y los demÃ¡s Serranos. Unos
y otros visten pieles, pero estos Ãºltimos, do quiera los encuentren, 
atacan Ã¡ los PampÃ­stas como Ã¡ sus enemigos mortales. Todos ellos pelean Ã¡ 
caballo, ya con lanzas enhastadas
con fierro Ã³ hueso aguzado, Ã³ bien con arcos y flechas. Usan
una especie de justillo de cuero de toro, para defender el
cuerpo. Los jefes que los comandan, tanto en la guerra como
en la paz, llÃ¡manles Curacas. Cuando toman alguno de sus
enemigos, ya sea vivo Ã³ muerto, ^e reÃºnen todos, y despuÃ©s
de reprocharle que Ã©l Ã³ sus parientes ocasionaron la muerte
de sus deudos Ã³ amigos, lo despedazan, y soazÃ¡ndolo un
poco se lo comen, con virtiendo el crÃ¡neo en vacijas para
beber. Se alimentan principalmente de carne cruda Ã³ cocida, y 
particularmente de carne de potrillo, que prefieren
Ã¡ la de ternera. Toman en los nos pescado en abundancia
y no tienen morada flja, sino que vagan de un lado Ã¡ otro
con sus familias, viviendo en toldos.
No pude averiguar con exactitud de quÃ© religiÃ³n eran,
pero dijÃ©ronme que tenian al sol y la luna por deidades, y
Ã¡ mi paso vi un salvaje arrodillado con la cara hacia el sol,
que daba gritos y accionaba de un modo estraÃ±o con los
brazos y las manos. Supe por el salvaje que me acompaÃ±aba, que era uno de 
aquellos Ã¡ quienes llaman Papas, quienes por la maÃ±anase arrodillan 
mirando al sol y en la noche cÃ¡ la luna, para suplicarÃ¡ aquellas supuestas 
divinidades
que les sean propicias, que les conceda buen tiempo y la
victoria sobre sus enemigos.
No son de gran aparato las ceremonias en sus casamientos; pero cuando 
muere un pariente, despuÃ©s de haber
dado friegas al cuerpo con cierta tierra que todo lo consume menos los 
huesos, conservan estos, llevando consigo
cuantos pueden en una especie de cajones, y esto lo hacen
en prueba de afecto Ã¡ sus deudos; y en verdad no faltan en
sus buenos oficios hcÃ¡cia ellos durante sus vidas, ni aun en
sus enfermedades y en su muerte.
Por la costa del Saladillo observÃ© gran nÃºmero de loros,
Ã³ segÃºn les llaman los espaÃ±oles, papagallos, y ciertos pÃ¡jaros llamados 
guacamayos, que son de diversos colores y
dos Ã³ tres veces mas grandes que un loro. El rio estÃ¡ lleno
del pescado que llaman dorado. TambiÃ©n hÃ¡llase en Ã©l un
animal de cuatro patas y con cola como un lagarto, pero si
es bueno como alimento, Ã³ nocivo, nadie lo sabe.
Del Saladillo hasta CÃ³rdoba, se sigue costeando un hermoso rio, que abunda 
en pescado, y que no es ni ancho ni
profundo, pudiÃ©ndose vadearlo. Sobre las barrancas de Ã©l
encuÃ©ntranse haciendas Ã¡ cada tres Ã³ cuatro leguas, que son
como casas de campo, habitadas por espaÃ±oles, portugueses Ã© hijos del paÃ­s 
en donde tienen todas las comodidades
de la vida que pueden apetecer, y son muy corteses y caritativos para con 
los estraÃ±os. Su principal riqueza consiste en caballos y muÃ­as, con los 
que trafican con los habitantes de PerÃº.
CÃ³rdoba es un pueblo situado en una llanura agradable
y feraz, Ã¡ la margen de un rio mas grande y mas ancho que
el de que acabo de hablar. Se compone como de 400 casas construidas como 
las de Buenos Aires. No tienen fosos,
murallas ni fortaleza para su defensa. El que manda alli es
Gobernador de todas las provincias de Tucuman, y aun
cuando este es el lugar de su residencia ordinaria, sin embargo, 
acostumbra de vez en cuando, segÃºn lo cree conveniente, ir Ã¡ pasar algÃºn 
tiempo en Santiago del Estero, en
San Miguel de Tucuman (que es la ciud id capital de la Provincia) en Salta 
Ã³ en Xuxui. En cada uno de estos pueblitos
existe un teniente, que tiene bajo sus Ã³rdenes un Alcalde y
algunos oficiales para la administraciÃ³n de justicia. El
obispo de Tucuman tambiÃ©n reside ordinariamente en CÃ³rdoba, en donde la 
Catedral es la Ãºnica iglesia parroquial
que hay en todo el pueblo; pero hay varios conventos de
frailes, Ã¡ saber, de Dominicos, Recoletos, y de la Orden de
la Merced; y uno de monjas. Los JesuÃ­tas tienen alli un
colegio, y su Capilla es la mas rica y mas hermosa de todas.
Los habitantes son ricos en oro y plata, adquiridos por
el comercio que hacen de muÃ­as, supliendo de ellas al PerÃº
y otros puntos; y es tan considerable Ã©ste que venden de 28
Ã¡ 30,000 al aÃ±o, que crian en sus haciendas. Generalmente
las conservan hasta que tienen dos aÃ±os poniÃ©ndolas entonces Ã¡ venta, 
obteniendo por ellas Ã¡ razÃ³n como de seis
patacones por cada una. Los mercaderes que vienen Ã¡
comprarlas las llevan Ã¡ Santiago, Ã¡ Salta y Ã¡ Xuxui, donde
las conservan tres aÃ±os hasta que se hayan creado y robustecido bien, 
llevÃ¡ndolas despuÃ©s al PerÃº, en donde las venden sin demora, porque alli, 
comoen el resto de la AmÃ©rica
occidental, la mayor parte de las conducciones se hacen Ã¡
lomo de muÃ­a.
Las gentes de CÃ³rdoba trafican tambiÃ©n en vacas que
conducen desde los campos de Buenos Aires hasta el PerÃº
en donde, sin este medio de subsistencia, ciertamente les
seria muy difÃ­cil vivir. Este negocio hace que este pueblo
sea el mas considerable dÃ©los de la Provincia de Tucuman,
tanto por sus riquezas y artÃ­culos de comercio, cuanto por
el nÃºmero de sus habitantes, que se calculan entre quinientas Ã¡ 
seiscientas familias, ademas de los esclavos, que montan Ã¡tres tantos mas.
Pero las clases todas, en general, no tienen mas arma que
espada y puÃ±al, y como soldados son de muy escaso mÃ©rito, pues el aire del 
paÃ­s y la abundancia de que gozan, los
hace holgazines y cobardes.
          </tei-p>
     </tei-div>

 </tei-text>

pageContext.rawContent:
Our Edition

Add text about the edition here.
